Line 20: Line 20:
== Live CD ==
== Live CD ==
â
dyne:bolic is designed from ground up to be used as LiveCD. It does not require installation to a hard drive, and attempts to recognize most devices and peripherals automatically (for example: sound, video, TV, etc). Its kernel is highly optimized for low latency and high performance, making it suitable for audio and video production.
+
dyne:bolic is designed from ground up to be used as Live CD. It does not require installation to a hard drive, and attempts to recognize most devices and peripherals automatically (for example: sound, video, TV, etc). Its kernel is highly optimized for low latency and high performance, making it suitable for audio and video production.
â
dyne:bolic is not based on any other existing LiveCD technology. Basic system requirements are relatively low: a PC with a Pentium MMX (i586) class CPU and 64 [[Megabyte|MB]] of RAM is sufficient. Some versions of dyne:bolic can be used on an [[Xbox]] game console (Xbox is not currently supported by v2.0).
+
dyne:bolic is not based on any other existing Live CD technology. Basic system requirements are relatively low: a PC with a Pentium MMX (i586) class CPU and 64 [[Megabyte|MB]] of RAM is sufficient. Some versions of dyne:bolic can be used on an [[Xbox]] game console (Xbox is not currently supported by v2.0).
== Installation ==
== Installation ==
â
Windows & Linux installation is simple & direct. The user copies the dyne directory from the CD (described in db literature as "Docking") to any suitably formatted partition or drive: this filesystem will be recognised and booted by the CD, or there is the option to install a bootloader or edit an existing one. Booting from floppy disk is also supported. Unlike other LiveCD technologies, dyne:bolic can save user settings in a file on a partition (or even user's own [[USB flash drive]]) which can also be encrypted for better privacy (described as "Nesting" in the db literature). [[Xfce]] is used as the [[desktop]] interface ([[Window Maker]] was used before 2.4).
+
Windows & Linux installation is simple & direct. The user copies the dyne directory from the CD (described in db literature as "Docking") to any suitably formatted partition or drive: this filesystem will be recognised and booted by the CD, or there is the option to install a bootloader or edit an existing one. Booting from floppy disk is also supported. Unlike other Live CD technologies, dyne:bolic can save user settings in a file on a partition (or even user's own [[USB flash drive]]) which can also be encrypted for better privacy (described as "Nesting" in the db literature). [[Xfce]] is used as the [[desktop]] interface ([[Window Maker]] was used before 2.4).
== Multimedia Support ==
== Multimedia Support ==
Line 38: Line 38:
The latest versions contain many [[JACK Audio Connection Kit]] applications and can automatically turn a network of computers into an [[openMosix]] cluster on booting for instant network-wide CPU clustering. This powerful feature allows a network of machines to work as a distributed supercomputing environment, and can be thought of as an out-of-the-box [[Render Farm]] supporting additional features useful in CPU-intensive environments.
The latest versions contain many [[JACK Audio Connection Kit]] applications and can automatically turn a network of computers into an [[openMosix]] cluster on booting for instant network-wide CPU clustering. This powerful feature allows a network of machines to work as a distributed supercomputing environment, and can be thought of as an out-of-the-box [[Render Farm]] supporting additional features useful in CPU-intensive environments.
â
A new feature in versions 2.0 and above is that it is truly "Live". Most LiveCD distributions are often a demo of Linux, and to have new software, one will have to wait for a new version. dyne:II is designed to be a truly "live" CD. Basically, Dyne:II is a core; while it can be run live as-is, it is also designed to be customized by placing additional modules (dynemodules) into the [[ISO image]], so that it may truly suit the users' needs.
+
A new feature in versions 2.0 and above is that it is truly "Live". Most Live CD distributions are often a demo of Linux, and to have new software, one will have to wait for a new version. dyne:II is designed to be a truly "live" CD. Basically, Dyne:II is a core; while it can be run live as-is, it is also designed to be customized by placing additional modules (dynemodules) into the [[ISO image]], so that it may truly suit the users' needs.
An example would be [[pure:dyne]], based on the dyne:II core.
An example would be [[pure:dyne]], based on the dyne:II core.
